body:
Another thing is that He shuffles the dataset for each epoch. I only tested on the CIFAR 10 dataset with ResNet56:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3815006/17655271/9685f9ac-62de-11e6-8863-162f92689902.png)

Note that 93.16% is about 1% higher than 92.17%. In the paper, the reference performance is 93.03% (93.16%>93.03%>92.17%). I am wondering this will also apply for the ImageNet dataset.

P.S.: Shuffling the whole dataset is expensive, so I am using the following `RandomSkipResizeIter`:

```
class RandomSkipResizeIter(mx.io.DataIter):
    """Resize a DataIter to given number of batches per epoch.
    May produce incomplete batch in the middle of an epoch due
    to padding from internal iterator.

    Parameters
    ----------
    data_iter : DataIter
        Internal data iterator.
    max_random_skip : maximum random skip number
        If max_random_skip is 1, no random skip.
    size : number of batches per epoch to resize to.
    reset_internal : whether to reset internal iterator on ResizeIter.reset
    """

    def __init__(self, data_iter, size, skip_ratio=0.5, reset_internal=False):
        super(RandomSkipResizeIter, self).__init__()
        self.data_iter = data_iter
        self.size = size
        self.reset_internal = reset_internal
        self.cur = 0
        self.current_batch = None
        self.prev_batch = None
        self.skip_ratio = skip_ratio

        self.provide_data = data_iter.provide_data
        self.provide_label = data_iter.provide_label
        self.batch_size = data_iter.batch_size

    def reset(self):
        self.cur = 0
        if self.reset_internal:
            self.data_iter.reset()

    def __get_next(self):
        try:
            return self.data_iter.next()
        except StopIteration:
            self.data_iter.reset()
            return self.data_iter.next()

    def iter_next(self):
        if self.cur == self.size:
            return False

        data, label = [], []
        if self.current_batch is None:
            # very first
            batch = self.__get_next()
            self.current_batch = mx.io.DataBatch(data=[mx.nd.empty(batch.data[0].shape)], label=[mx.nd.empty(batch.label[0].shape)])
            keep = np.random.rand(self.batch_size) > self.skip_ratio
            batch_data = batch.data[0].asnumpy()
            batch_label = batch.label[0].asnumpy()
            data.extend(batch_data[keep])
            label.extend(batch_label[keep])
        elif self.prev_batch is not None:
            # prev_batch
            batch_data, batch_label = self.prev_batch
            data.extend(batch_data)
            label.extend(batch_label)

        while len(data) < self.batch_size:
            batch = self.__get_next()
            keep = np.random.rand(self.batch_size) > self.skip_ratio
            batch_data = batch.data[0].asnumpy()
            batch_label = batch.label[0].asnumpy()
            data.extend(batch_data[keep])
            label.extend(batch_label[keep])

        if len(data) > self.batch_size:
            self.prev_batch = data[self.batch_size:], label[self.batch_size:]
        else:
            self.prev_batch = None
        self.current_batch.data[0][:] = np.asarray(data[:self.batch_size])
        self.current_batch.label[0][:] = np.asarray(label[:self.batch_size])

        self.cur += 1
        return True

    def getdata(self):
        return self.current_batch.data

    def getlabel(self):
        return self.current_batch.label

    def getindex(self):
        return self.current_batch.index

    def getpad(self):
        return self.current_batch.pad
```

Going to close this. It should probably be be moved to MShadow and then use SimpleOp. This implementation is incorrect for GPU anyways.

@antinucleon, @pluskid, @freddycct @yzhang87: whilst discussing this layer, I'm also interested in adding a SequenceReverse layer:
- takes two arguments, "data" of the form [sequence, batch, rest], and "sequence_length", a vector of integers >=1 and of length batch. Returns another tensor of the same size as the input.
  leaves padding unchanged.

Its needed for bidirectional RNN's etc. The design should be consistent with SequenceLast. 

One other thing: I'm implementing these via CUDA + C++. Is there an easier way, or would this also be your recommended approach? And should these implementations be in MShadow (similar to softmax), or live in MXNet layer definition?
Please update to latest master, so that I can merge
@taoari This PR is good to merge. Please update to the latest master to merge.

@antinucleon: I'm also interested to know why you chose to use actual masks for the new element_mask layer, rather than lists of sequence lengths (with a function name SequenceMask or something). Lists of sequence lengths seem like the more general solution (for example, for SequenceReverse layer, you need to know where to reverse from), and more memory efficient.

I have this few changes for the Elastic SGD to work..The changes are to the python/mxnet/model.py on local and remote updates. The changes look straight forward to me but I may be missing something as the learning I observe is very poor..pasting what I did below:

  """ Perform update of param_arrays from central variables on kvstore. Use grad arrays to pull in the center variables"""

`def _update_params_on_kvstore(param_arrays, grad_arrays, kvstore):

```
   for index, pair in enumerate(zip(param_arrays, grad_arrays)):
    arg_list, grad_list = pair
    if grad_list[0] is None:
        continue
    # push back the weights
    kvstore.push(index, arg_list, priority=-index)
    # pull center variables into gradient, priority is negative index
    kvstore.pull(index, grad_list, priority=-index)
    for p in zip(arg_list, grad_list):
        w, g = p
         w -= alpha * (w-g)`
```

  """ Perform update of param_arrays  not on kvstore."""
def _update_params(param_arrays, grad_arrays, updater, num_device,
                   kvstore=None):

` for index, pair in enumerate(zip(param_arrays, grad_arrays)):

```
    arg_list, grad_list = pair
    if grad_list[0] is None:
        continue
    for k, p in enumerate(zip(arg_list, grad_list)):
        # faked an index here, to make optimizer create diff
        # state for the same index but on diff devs, TODO(mli)
        # use a better solution latter
        w, g = p
        updater(index*num_device+k, g, w)`
```

In the main iter loop I do:

`
           _update_params_on_kvstore(executor_manager.param_arrays,
                                          executor_manager.grad_arrays,
                                          kvstore)
                executor_manager.forward(is_train=True)
                executor_manager.backward()
                _update_params(executor_manager.param_arrays,
                              executor_manager.grad_arrays,
                              updater=updater,
                              num_device=len(ctx),
                              kvstore=kvstore)
`

Modify the Makefile of the speech demo:
Change the following line

```
ADDLIBS = ../util/kaldi-util.a ../matrix/kaldi-matrix.a ../base/kaldi-base.a  ../hmm/kaldi-hmm.a ../cudamatrix/kaldi-cudamatrix.a ../nnet/kaldi-nnet.a

```
ADDLIBS = ../util/kaldi-util.a ../matrix/kaldi-matrix.a ../base/kaldi-base.a  ../hmm/kaldi-hmm.a ../cudamatrix/kaldi-cudamatrix.a ../nnet/kaldi-nnet.a ../thread/kaldi-thread.a
```

i'm training resnet-50 from scrach( without pre-trained model) these days, when i used one BN layer(fix_gamma=True) in the data for doing  z-score, then the BN code in currently mxnet will give right training acc but wrong test acc.  
the reason is that even fix_gamma=True, the weight decay will change the gamma value through sgd, so during test phase, we should fix it as above. but i'm not sure whether this will influence the existed pre-trained model, so not give a pr at that time.

About sequence Len vs mask. I think we came up with the mask idea because that is the most straightforward way to implement in our current code base, you just need to have a broadcasting multiplication.

However, if we are to do rnn symbol fusion that encapsulate the whole operation as a big operator, then underlying I guess using either would be fine.

Mask is slightly more general as one could put more than one very short sequences in one slot when batching with very long sequences. However, I am not sure how often we need to do this or how useful it is, and it is probably not useful for bidirectional or more complicated models.

In summary, I guess if we are to do rnn fusion, we may choose whatever makes it easy to do internal implementation. It seems seq Len is easier as it is of more constrained case. For example, if you need to reverse the sequences, etc
Great! This is fast!

Hi @zhangjiulong! Nice catch! I guess that is the issue. I can confirm adding `kaldi-thread.a` still compiles correctly on my side. I have created a PR to add this.

There seem to be some issue causing the first CUDA api call to be very slow. Can you make a call of `zeros` on both GPU and CPU first to warm up, and then measure the call time?
Can you add an entry to [NEWS](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/NEWS.md) under the ongoing v1.0 milestone and list it as breaking changes?

So what do you guys recommend to do right now? I've double checked the behaviour of FlatTo2D hasn't been changed as @piiswrong has mentioned.  

If the intended operation is ambiguous, how about using two parameters, "across_channel" and "across_spatial", and perform normalization accordingly?

This is because by default, the CSVIter has `round_batch` being True. Which means with batch size 3, and total instance 10, two more examples are consumed at the first round. When you call `reset`, the call is ignored because the second round has already begun due to the round padding. As a result, you got fewer examples in the second round.

The behavior of `FlatTo2D` has not changed for backward compatibility, we used `get_with_shape` and `ProdShape` instead, for [example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/fully_connected-inl.h#L75).

I believe the OP's issue is due to threaded prefetching. The thread started prefetching once the data iter is created and then a `reset` call interrupted it. The "correct" way is to avoid calling `reset()` until a first round over the data iter is finished. For example, in the OP's test code, if the `reset()` call is moved to the end of `print_iter`, then you will see the expected behavior.
I edited the comment, it was wrong because the actual network is much more bigger. I will try the batch size and tell you what happens. Thanks @thirdwing

@R1ncy By set `round_batch = False` , we can get same sample each round.

```
train = mx.io.CSVIter(
    data_csv="./feature.csv" ,
    label_csv="./label.csv" ,
    data_shape = (2,) ,

I have solved this problem by extracting the libmxnet-scala.so from the mxnet-full_2.10-linux-x86_64-cpu-0.1.2-SNAPSHOT.jar. The only difference is I only used cpu mode.
$ jar -tf mxnet-full_2.10-linux-x86_64-cpu-0.1.2-SNAPSHOT.jar| grep mxnet-scala --color
$ lib/native/libmxnet-scala.so
Using "jar -xf mxnet-full_2.10-linux-x86_64-cpu-0.1.2-SNAPSHOT.jar" to extract the libmxnet-scala.so
After that, manually put the  libmxnet-scala.so to the java library path.
That works for me.

There are [many issues](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=opencv%20GPU%20slow) that seem to be related. Recompiling openCV withOUT GPU support seem to resolve those issues.

Your contribution is welcomed :)

You can use data parallel to run several images together on multi-gpu. It will not speed up the calculation of single image. It is equivalent to run them individually on different GPUs, since there is no model parameter update.
Building Opencv without GPU should solve this issue. Please reopen it if you find it do not work.

Do you use the same MXNet version? The behavior of Pooling Op has been changed in one PR to make it compatible with CuDNN
